intro: Antheryta, commonly known as the "flowering rush," is a genus of aquatic plants belonging to the family Cyperaceae. It is characterized by its tall, slender stems that often emerge from wetland environments. The plant produces dense clusters of small, greenish-white flowers, which are typically arranged in spike-like inflorescences. Antheryta thrives in shallow water and moist soil, making it a common sight in marshes and along the edges of ponds. Its botanical features make it an important component of wetland ecosystems.
